document.masterDocTitle: A further study on the wolf spider subfamily Artoriinae from China (Araneae: Lycosidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Hygrolycosa ligulacea
Qu et al. , 2009: 71
, figs 1a–c, 2a–d ( ♂ ♀ ).

Artoria ligulacea :
Li et al. 2012: 40
, figs 4A–I, 5A–E ( ♂ ♀ ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species resembles
A. parvula Thorell, 1877
( Figs 9–10 ), but can be distinguished from the latter by the distal end of median apophysis somewhat like the head of a cobra snake, with bent tip ( Figs 7A–B , 8D–E ), whereas distal end curved triangular with ventrally bent tip in
A. parvula
( Figs 9A–B , 10D–E ), basoembolic apophysis longer than wide, highly sclerotized ( Figs 7A, C , 8D, F ), whereas almost round and not sclerotized in
A. parvula
( Figs 9A, C , 10D–F ). Posterior margin of epigyne straight ( Figs 7D–E , 8G–H ), whereas posterior margin with a depression in
A. parvula
( Figs 9D–E , 10G–H ). Spermathecal head not furcated ( Figs 7E , 8H ), whereas furcated into two branches in
A. parvula
( Figs 9E , 10H ).

Description. See
Li et al. (2012)
for both sexes. Habitus, male pedipalp, and epigyne as in Figs 7–8 .

Material examined.

Distribution. Previously known from Yunnan Province of China only, but here reported from further east and north, to the Guizhou and Sichuan Provinces of China ( Fig. 11 ).
